The Management System of Ottoman Empire in Arab World 1516 - 1916 : The Ottoman Turks followed quite pragmatic and realistic policies in the Arab geography. They did not completely abolish the previous administrative structure and accepted the existing codes of law.The properties and foundations remained untouched.The amount of taxes did not changeillegal and excessive taxes were abolished.The Ottomans maintained the existing system in the mountainous regions of Iraq and Lebanoncertain settlements were left to the authority of prominent local families. Closer regions to Anatolia such as Syria and Palestine were directly connected to the central authority through governors and ‘kadı’ [Muslim judges].Ottomans governed regions such as Egypt, Tunisia, Algeria and Iraq in a more ‘liberal’ fashion with a more autonomous system.Holy cities such as Mecca and Medina were left to the authority of local sharifs [nobilities].While the Muslim Arabs were free to practice their language and culture, the non-Muslim Arabs were part of the “Millet System”The status of heterodox communities such as the Druze and Yazidis was a bit more different. The Yazidis were accepted neither as Muslims, nor non-Muslims, while the Druze was affiliated to the Sunni-Hanafi law [closer to the Ottoman system].According to the “Cebel-i Lübnan/Mount Lebanon (1864)” lawbook, the Druze was recognized as a seperate community under the autonomous administration of Cebel-i Lübnan province [sanjak].These communities always lived under Sunni administrations such as Seljuk, Umayyad, Mamluk, and continued living in the mountainous and rural regions during the Ottoman period as well.The Ottomans did not intervene into their lives as long as they remained loyal to the state. The unhindered bedouin attacks against the state authority was the biggest problem faced by the Ottomans. Another problem was the unlawful acts of some governors and ‘kadıs’.In Summary, history must be evaluated and written based on the conditions of the era in particular, not fantasiesEgypt; enjoyed a high level of self rule under the Ottomans through the dynasty of the Wali Mohammad Ali. Egypt thrived and prospered under the ottomans, and the modern Egyptian army was basically created and modeled after the Turks by Mohammed Ali, replacing years of rule by the Mamluks. The ottomans (Mohammed Ali) continued to rule through Khedive Ismail, King Fouad, and King Farouq and they were more or less considered as an Egyptian dynasty rather than a Turkish/Albanian one, until the military overthrew the King in the 1952 coup. After the coup most of the schoolbooks and history was re-written to smear the reputation of the Ottomans and the overthrown king, and most Egyptians now have a negative view of the Ottomans as foreign invaders and brutal occupiers .Northern Africa and the Maghreb region : These countries have a generally positive view of the Ottomans. They were ruled somewhat independently and there were many instances of support and collaboration between them and the Ottomans against common enemies and in strengthening their internal governance and protecting them from foreign aggression.n Algeria, the Ottoman Empire was seen a bit positive rather than any other. There are reasons contributed for the positive attitude:- The Ottomans gave Algeria a decent of autonomy like Tunisia.- Algeria was too far away to create any threats for Constantinople- Many revered figures like Hayreddin Barbarossa and Abdelkader el Dzajiri were heroes of both Turkey and Algeria.- People in here have strong impression and acceptance of Ottoman rule.Most Algerians have negative view on French colonial rule rather than with the Turks, but again, it is varied.Tunisia : Ottoman empire is highly regarded in Tunisia, the vast majority here only speak good about the Ottoman empire but to them, the Ottoman empire ended in 1881, the year in which France invaded Tunisia and took it from the Ottoman empire, after this year, there is almost zero or at least a very little mention of
